entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #15
entry.summary: Yosemite - what a place! It dates back to President Abraham Lincoln declaring Yosemite federally preserved land, followed by John Muir leading the effort in 1890 to have Yosemite Valley and the surrounding area established as a national park. It's not hard to see why…
entry.content:
Yosemite - what a place!  It dates back to President Abraham Lincoln declaring Yosemite federally preserved land, followed by John Muir leading the effort in 1890 to have Yosemite Valley and the surrounding area established as a national park.  It's not hard to see why approximately 4 million visitors come here each year - the views are spectacular, no matter where you look when you are in Yosemite Valley.

We left Rush Creek Lodge around 8:30 and drove into the park

We stopped at a couple of viewpoints along the way.

The most famous viewpoint is Tunnel View, where you can see the whole valley off in the distance.

There are so many places to stop and walk for a bit and take in the view.  

Even though it was off-season, the park was still very busy, and it was difficult to find parking spots.  We eventually found a spot and stopped for lunch.

We took a two mile hike to Mirror Lake.  The path threaded through some huge boulders.

There was a warning sign at the start of the hike...

Although it's called Mirror Lake - the lake bed is completely dry right now.  This is a combination of the time of year (lowest water flow in the fall) and an ongoing drought.  You can see on the rock in the middle of the lake bed what the normal water level would have been.

A mountain face is visible from here, and some could see climbers on the rock - my eyes weren't sharp enough to capture it.

We walked over to the Village Lodge for a cold drink and then visited the lower Yosemite falls on our way back to the van.  Again, very little water flow at this time of year.

We got on the road again around 4:30 to head home.  We took a different pass through the mountains home - it wasn't quite as scary as the one we took to get here!  Home about 8:30 pm - ready for bed!

Here are a few more photos from the day...

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #14
entry.summary: We left this afternoon for Yosemite - Mitch driving and me navigating our way out of the Bay Area - quite a network of highways and plenty of traffic even on an early monday afternoon. Eventually we left built up areas behind and drove through…
entry.content:
We left this afternoon for Yosemite - Mitch driving and me navigating our way out of the Bay Area - quite a network of highways and plenty of traffic even on an early monday afternoon.  Eventually we left built up areas behind and drove through farming country - thousands of almond trees, interspersed with canals to provide irrigation.  After heading south we turned east and headed into the mountains going through the Sonora Pass.  Apparently it is the second highest in California and it certainly felt like it!  You need your wits about you, and I would not want to drive it in the dark.

The road is basically cut into the side of the hill and climbs steadily upward.  A sign at the start suggests shutting of your air conditioning for the next five miles to reduce the strain on the engine.  We eventually arrived at Rush Creek Lodge, a beautiful spot a few miles west of Yosemite.  The lodge consists of several buildings including a restaurant, a lounge area and a pool and it is really pretty when lit up at night.

We had supper in the restaurant before heading back to our room and waiting for it to get dark so we could go check out the stars in Yosemite.

Around 8pm, we drove 30 minutes into the park to an open spot where we could see the stars.  There was quite a bit of moonlight so conditions weren't ideal, but we could still see quite a few stars.  You lay down on your back on the ground and wait for your eyes to adjust to the darkness (and hope there are no bears nearby looking for a bedtime snack).  I didn't get any photos of this as you really need a tripod to have a long exposure in order to see much of anything in the shot.

We headed back to our hotel for the night.  It is a very comfortable room, but the wall art is a bit disturbing!  I guess it fits with the mountain theme!

Tomorrow we plan to head in to Yosemite for the day.

entry.summary: Another quiet day with no driving! Janet and I were up at 6 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 6:30 our time (9:30 Ottawa time). We also enjoyed Aaron's ministry session at 8:45/11:45 on Mitch's big screen. We walked about 15 minutes to…
entry.content:
Another quiet day with no driving!  Janet and I were up at 6 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 6:30 our time (9:30 Ottawa time).  We also enjoyed Aaron's ministry session at 8:45/11:45 on Mitch's big screen.

We walked about 15 minutes to a spot called Heavenly Bistro for brunch.  A busy place and we had to wait a while to get seated, but it was worth it!  French toast, eggs, bacon and sausage - well fueled for the day!

Another beautiful day here - the weather seems pretty reliable at 20-25 degrees and sunny.  We took this bridge over one of the busy streets - it connects up with the BART - Bay Area Rapid Transit system.  Mitch uses this to get into the office in San Francisco, about 40 minutes away.

Lots of greenery and a pleasant place to walk around.  

We swam in the condo pool outside Mitch's patio and sat reading and enjoying the sun.  The palm trees seem impossibly tall - not sure how they stay up there!

Tomorrow afternoon we plan to head to Yosemite National Park with Mitch, about 3.5 hours away.  He has been there a couple of times before so can show us around.  We plan to stay overnight near the park and head back to Walnut Creek on Tuesday.

entry.content:
Today was lovely quiet day at Mitch's place with no driving!  We did all our laundry in the morning, and in the afternoon we went for a walk on the trails near his place.  

We followed the trail to a nearby park where there were lots of families and kids playing.

There was a little lending library on the way...

There were some beautiful roses along the way...

Mitch made scones this afternoon and we had them with tea.  For supper he made pasta with marinara sauce, and crepes for dessert - we are eating well!  Tomorrow we will be up bright and early at 6:30 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 9:30 EST.

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #11
entry.summary: This morning we walked down the street from our hotel to a cafe that opened at 6:30 am to get coffee and a muffin. It was just getting light, and the main street looked very pretty. The coffee shop is an eclectic space filled with…
entry.content:
This morning we walked down the street from our hotel to a cafe that opened at 6:30 am to get coffee and a muffin. It was just getting light, and the main street looked very pretty.

The coffee shop is an eclectic space filled with books, knicknacks, paintings and kayaks!  It is a shared space with a workshop where kayaks and other things are made in the back, with the cafe area in the front.

Janet was keen to check out a fabric shop, but as it didn't open until 10 and we wanted to get to San Francisco before supper, we decided to head out.

We drove south on highway 101 until we reached Humbolt Redwoods State Park.  There is a road through the park that runs parallel to the 101 called Avenue of the Giants.  We took this road, and stopped and did a 2 mile hike through a grove of redwoods - these trees are hundreds of years old, and some reach heights of 360 feet - the tallest living things on the planet.  The only way to get a sense of their size is to have someone in the picture for perspective.  Apparently these trees were slated to be logged early in the 1900s to make shingles and stakes for growing grapes, and a group of people banded together to buy up tracks of redwoods to prevent this. They considered that chopping these giant trees down for such utiltarian items was the equivalent of chopping up a grandfather clock to make kindling wood.  Eventually these areas were turned into state parks and the trees preserved.  

We ate our lunch at the visitors center there and then drove on.  As we got nearer to San Francisco, the hills were yellow/brown shades with green spots of trees. 

We crossed the Richmond San Rafael Bridge to get over to the Oakland side of the bay and headed into Walnut Creek where Mitch lives.  Lots of traffic and Janet drove while I navigated.

You can see San Francisco in the distance above the fog in the photo below, taken from the bridge.

We arrived at Mitch's place around 4:45 pm - so nice to see him again!

Mitch gave us a quick tour of the condo grounds - a beautiful spot.

Very happy to be safely here - we covered a total of 5905 kilometres to get here from Ottawa!  Now we plan to enjoy a couple of quiet days with no driving!

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #10
entry.summary: Today will be another challenge to decide what photos to include! We left Lincoln City this morning at 7:30 in misty rain and fog and drove down Highway 101 along the Oregon coast. We weren't sure what we would be able to see with all…
entry.content:
Today will be another challenge to decide what photos to include!  We left Lincoln City this morning at 7:30 in misty rain and fog and drove down Highway 101 along the Oregon coast.  We weren't sure what we would be able to see with all the fog, but it turned out to be spectacular!

There are so many spots to stop and take in the view or walk down to the beach.  We had quite a few miles to cover today so we couldn't stop everywhere. 

We did pull into the Yaquina Head Lighthouse park to check out the lighthouse and then to head down the stairs to the shore below.

As we drove south, the weather gradually cleared and eventually turned sunny.

You can see a couple of surfers in the photo below - I'm sure the water is pretty chilly!

We drove through thick groves of redwoods, beautiful tall trees.  With all the rain and mist off the water, the vegetation is lush and green, with moss hanging from tree branches.

We crossed a few bridges too - some under construction or refurbishment, but others that looked to have been there a long time.

We stopped at a used book store in Gold Beach - thousands of books well-organized, and a few pieces of art, including a life-sized Elvis..

We picked up coffees and headed on south....stopping for supper in Eureka.

Our hotel for tonight is the Victorian Inn, located in a little town called Ferndale, California.  The hotel dates back to 1890, and the whole village is a historic site.  It is certainly a change from the Holiday Inn Express!

 

Tomorrow we hope to check out the town a bit more before heading to Mitch's place in Walnut Creek.  It should be about 4.5 hours of driving, so much shorter than today's 7.5 hours (which turned into nearly 10 hours with all our stops).

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #9
entry.summary: We were on the road by 8:15 this morning and headed for Portland and on to the Oregon Coast. As soon as we crossed the Columbia River we were in Oregon. The interstate then followed the south bank of the Columbia River for many miles.
entry.content:
We were on the road by 8:15 this morning and headed for Portland and on to the Oregon Coast.  As soon as we crossed the Columbia River we were in Oregon.  The interstate then followed the south bank of the Columbia River for many miles.  It's a big river, with train tracks running along both sides of it, and very few towns along its banks - it seems quite desolate.

Eventually we came to Portland and then headed south-west towards the coast.  The landscape is much greener here - lots of trees, vineyards and orchards.  

As we got closer to the coast, we entered a forested area with big trees thickly lining the winding road.

We arrived in Lincoln City on the coast around 2pm.  Checked into our hotel, and walked over to a nearby Starbucks for coffee.  Since we had some time before supper I decided to get the oil changed at a Valvoline drive in place just down the road.  On the way back I stopped at the beach and watched the waves rolling in...

We decided to walk to a nearby fish and chip place for supper.  

The owner was the talkative sort - he said he works 12 hours a day and so far today has 14,000 steps for today alone.  He also told us this place has the best fish and chips in the state of Oregon.  It was excellent - thin, crispy batter and flaky fish - we had some halibut and cod.

We walked back to our hotel in the light rain, feeling very full indeed!

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #8
entry.summary: Beautiful sunrise this morning from our hotel room... Breakfast starts at 6 and we were there when they opened! This hotel (Country Inn by Radisson) has the best breakfast so far! We were off about 8:30. We had decided to take a more scenic route…
entry.content:
Beautiful sunrise this morning from our hotel room...

Breakfast starts at 6 and we were there when they opened!  This hotel (Country Inn by Radisson) has the best breakfast so far!  

We were off about 8:30.  We had decided to take a more scenic route through the Kootenai National Forest, but google maps kept trying to re-route us using interstate highways, so we ended up circling around Kalispell before actually getting underway. We were glad we took the National Forest route as although it added 30 minutes of driving, it was a lot more scenic (although nothing could match yesterday in Glacier National Park).

We ended up traveling through three states today (Montana, Idaho, Washington) and one time zone change so we are now three hours behind Ottawa.  I didn't realize that a narrow slice of Idaho comes up between Montana and Washington until we saw the road signs.

There are still lots of mountains, although more like the green mountains of Vermont.  In many places there were misty clouds amongst the hills, perhaps because of the colder air temperature.  We passed through several little towns in the valleys - Libby, Troy, and then into Idaho and a bigger city called Bonner's Ferry.

We stopped for lunch by this lake. 

From there, Janet drove the rest of the way to our hotel in Pasco/Tri-Cities in Washington, about mid-way between Spokane and Portland.  The landscape here is much flatter - more like the eastern parts of Montana.  It is 29 degrees here - quite a change from 4 degrees this morning in Montana.  We hope to get to the coast tomorrow!

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #7
entry.summary: We made an early start this morning from Great Falls and headed north towards Glacier National Park. All along the way we could see the mountains to our left. Eventually we left the interstate and headed west towards those mountains and the entrance to the…
entry.content:
We made an early start this morning from Great Falls and headed north towards Glacier National Park.  All along the way we could see the mountains to our left.  Eventually we left the interstate and headed west towards those mountains and the entrance to the park.  We were taking the "Going to the Sun" road which crosses through the park via Logan pass.  This road is only open in the summer and fall until early October.  It is narrow, winding, with the most incredible views imaginable.  Fortunately there are frequent areas where you can pull off the road to take pictures.  In the summer the road is so popular that you have to reserve a spot in advance for the day you want to drive it to help them manage the traffic flows.  It was busy today too, but not too bad.  Every corner brings into view a new vista - it is very hard to capture it in photos...

You wind up to the mountain pass for the first part of the drive, and at times you can see the road after the pass down in the valley far below.  The road hugs the mountain side and there is a steep drop off to the left for most of the way.  This photo gives you an idea...

We stopped part way through and had our lunch and then continued on.  Eventually you descend from the pass and follow the river bottom to the other side of the mountain range.

The river eventually empties into a large lake....

It is without doubt the most spectacular drive I've ever been on!

We drove to a town on the west side of the park called Kalispell where our hotel for the night was located.  We were blessed with beautiful weather all day - sunshine and 20 degrees.

PS - I decided to add in a few more photos - there are so many to choose from!

entry.title: USA Road Trip - Post #6
entry.summary: We were up early this morning - with the time change we are waking up about 5am. We had breakfast in the hotel and then headed for the meeting in Sun River, a small town about 20 minutes from Great Falls. The meeting is comprised…
entry.content:
We were up early this morning - with the time change we are waking up about 5am.  We had breakfast in the hotel and then headed for the meeting in Sun River, a small town about 20 minutes from Great Falls.  The meeting is comprised of a number of people who have left Hutterite colonies in the area along with some others, and lots of kids!  Joe and Penny Clark kindly invited us to their place for lunch.  They live on the top of a hill above the town, with fields and blue sky all around.

We left their house about 2:30 to head back to Great Falls.  A beautiful drive - horses, cattle, some sheep...

The scenery here is spectacular everywhere...

Back at our hotel, I had a nap, and then we walked over to the grocery store next door to get some supplies for tomorrow, as well as something for supper tonight, although we don't need much after a big lunch.  We hope to make an early start tomorrow for the drive through Glacier National Park.
